channel.title: Bloomberg Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: New York Republicans Signal $80,000 SALT Cap Could Be on Table
item.description: Two New York Republicans signaled that the cap on the state and local tax deduction may rise to as much as $80,000 as GOP lawmakers from high-tax states demand a boost in exchange for their votes on President Donald Trump’s tax package.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum, Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: Representative Nicole Malliotakis

item.title: How Proposed Medicaid Cuts Would Cost 8 Million People Health Coverage
item.description: Republicans in Congress are negotiating a massive legislative package to realize President Donald Trump’s domestic agenda, and it won’t come cheap. Legislation advanced by House Republicans would cut taxes by almost $4.5 trillion over a decade and add hundreds of billions of dollars in new spending for defense, border wall construction, immigrant detention centers and other administration priorities.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Cohrs Zhang

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators during a markup of President Donald Trump’s tax package in Washington, DC, on May 13.

item.title: US Lawmakers Urge Ban on China-Linked Router Maker TP-Link
item.description: Seventeen Republican lawmakers urged the Commerce Department to prohibit further sales of equipment from TP-Link Systems Inc., a Wi-Fi router maker whose links to China have raised concerns and prompted investigations in the US.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: Workers on the production line at a TP-Link workshop in Shenzhen, China. Photographer: Liang Xu/Xinhua/Getty Images

item.title: Qatar’s PM Defends Jet Offer, Says They’ll Withdraw If Illegal
item.description: Qatar’s prime minister defended his country’s offer of a luxury jet to President Donald Trump, telling CNN they would not follow through with the gift if it was deemed illegal and insisting it was not an effort to wield undue influence within the US.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: Qatar's Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani (R) and US President Donald Trump arrive at the Royal Palace in Doha, accompanied by Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani (L) on May 14, 2025.

item.title: Senate Blocks Colombia Labor Refendum in Defeat for Petro
item.description: Colombian President Gustavo Petro suffered a major setback on Wednesday as the senate blocked his plan to hold a referendum on boosting workers’ rights.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina

media:content.media:description: Supporters of Gustavo Petro, Colombia’s president, during a demonstration on Labor Day in Bogota, Colombia, on Thursday, May 1, 2025. Petro presented a bill on Thursday that seeks to submit proposals for labor rights and working conditions to a public referendum after Congress rejected his labor reform earlier this year.

item.title: Trump’s Mideast Visit Opens Floodgate of AI Deals Led by Nvidia
item.description: The Trump administration is clearing a path for two key Persian Gulf allies to pursue their artificial intelligence ambitions — and some of the biggest US tech companies are seizing on that opening with plans to spend billions of dollars in the region.
item.dc:creator: Michael Shepard, Mackenzie Hawkins, Ian King

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump speaks during the Saudi-US business investment forum in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on May 13, 2025.

item.title: Republican Tax Plan Targets Clean-Energy Supplies Tied to China
item.description: A Republican tax plan seeking to cut clean-energy subsidies includes provisions that threaten to end the incentives even earlier than proposed.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: An employee inspects photovoltaic modules at the Longi Green Energy Technology Co. solar panel factory in Xi'an, Shaanxi Province, China, on Monday, July 20, 2020. Longi is the world's largest producer of solar wafers and the world's largest solar company by market value.

item.title: Putin Names Low-Level Officials for Talks With Ukraine in Turkey
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin named a group of low-level officials to represent his government at talks with Ukraine in Turkey, and gave no indication that he planned to join the negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Presidential Aide Vladimir Medinsky in Samolva, Russia, in 2021.

item.title: Harvard President Garber Takes 25% Pay Cut Amid Trump Fight
item.description: Harvard University President Alan Garber will take a voluntary 25% pay cut for the academic year that starts July 1, a school spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: Janet Lorin, Greg Ryan

media:content.media:description: Alan Garber

item.title: Judge Indicted for Blocking Migrant’s Arrest Claims Immunity
item.description: A Wisconsin state judge indicted for allegedly obstructing the arrest of a Mexican immigrant by US authorities said the charges should be dismissed because she’s immune from prosecution for official acts — a legal defense similar to one used by President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Steve Stroth

media:content.media:description: Hannah Dugan

item.title: Why Trade Deals and Tax Cuts May Be a Recipe for US Success
item.description: On this week’s Trumponomics, Stephen Moore of the Heritage Foundation argues that Donald Trump and the GOP Congress are on the right path.
item.dc:creator: Sommer Saadi, Stephanie Flanders

media:content.media:description: Stephen Moore, visiting fellow at the Heritage Foundation, listens during a discussion at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) in National Harbor, Maryland, U.S., on Friday, Feb. 28, 2020. President Trump will address this years CPAC after seeking to close ranks within his administration about the threat posed by the coronavirus and how the U.S. government plans to stop its spread following mixed messages that rattled Wall Street.

item.title: What’s Happening in Syria, and Why Is Trump Lifting Sanctions?
item.description: Since the toppling of President Bashar al-Assad’s regime in December, Syrians who endured more than half a century of state repression and 13 years of civil conflict finally have a reason for optimism.
item.dc:creator: Selcan Hacaoglu, Sam Dagher

media:content.media:description: Sharaa addresses a crowd at Damascus’ landmark Umayyad Mosque on Dec. 8.

item.title: South Africa’s Ramaphosa Heads to US to Ease Tensions With Trump
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa plans to hold talks with his US counterpart Donald Trump in Washington on May 21 and hopes to ease a simmering diplomatic row between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: Cyril Ramaphosa, South Africa's president, during a news conference following a meeting with Volodymyr Zelenskiy, Ukraine's president, at the Union Buildings in Pretoria, South Africa, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. President Volodymyr Zelenskiy became the fist leader of Ukraine to visit South Africa in a bid to expand diplomatic outreach while he can no longer fully rely on US as his nation’s key ally and the peace deal with Russia remains elusive.

item.title: Peru’s Endless Political Churn Is Spreading to the Finance Minister Post
item.description: Peru’s messy cabinet reshuffle is spotlighting how political instability is spreading to what was once a treasured post: the finance minister.
item.dc:creator: Marcelo Rochabrun, Maria Elena Vizcaino

media:content.media:description: Dina Boluarte Photographer: Carlos Garcia Granthon/Fotoholica Press/LightRocket/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Wants Supreme Court to Rein In Judges Thwarting His Agenda
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, senior Supreme Court correspondent Greg Stohr previews arguments before the court tomorrow in a case about the power of judges to stall the president’s agenda. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

item.title: UK Mulls New Investor Visa Targeting Key Strategic Industries
item.description: The UK is drawing up plans for a special visa for foreigners who invest significant sums in Britain, as Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s government seeks to blunt the economic blow from recent tax hikes and wider curbs on work permits.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Alex Wickham

item.title: Key House Panel Advances Medicaid Cuts in Republican Tax Package
item.description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee voted Wednesday to advance Republican plans to cut federal funding for Medicaid, the US health insurance program for low-income and disabled people.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Cohrs Zhang

media:content.media:description: A pharmacy technician prepares a prescription at a pharmacy in Portland, Maine.

item.title: Republican Plan to Sell $88 Billion of Radio Spectrum Faces Fight
item.description: Top Republicans are planning to auction $88 billion worth of radio spectrum to wireless broadband companies Verizon Communications Inc. and Elon Musk’s Starlink to help pay for their massive tax package — but the proposal faces stiff opposition from senators concerned about the potential impact to defense systems.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis, Oma Seddiq

media:content.media:description: A Ukrainian uses a Starlink satellite-internet communication system on a rooftop in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Tuesday, March 11, 2025. European Defense Commissoiner Andrius Kubilius expressed confidence that the EU would be able to replace the Starlink satellite communications system quickly in Ukraine if owner Elon Musk were to pull the plug. Photographer: Andrew Kravchenko/Bloomberg

item.title: Harvard to Fund $250 Million for Research After Trump Scraps Federal Money
item.description: Harvard University said it will free up an extra $250 million of school money to help pay for research during the coming year after the Trump administration scrapped multiyear federal funding of more than $2.6 billion.
item.dc:creator: Janet Lorin

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians walk through Harvard Yard on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

item.title: Carney Delays Canada Budget, Plans to Cut Income Tax by July
item.description: Canada will cut the lowest personal income tax rate to 14% from 15% on July 1, but Prime Minister Mark Carney’s new government won’t release a budget before the summer months.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney during a news conference with cabinet members after a swearing-in ceremony at Rideau Hall in Ottawa, Ontario, on May 13.

item.title: Thiam Makes Surprise Return as Leader of Ivorian Opposition
item.description: Former Credit Suisse Group AG Chief Executive Officer Tidjane Thiam was re-elected to lead Ivory Coast’s main opposition party days after he resigned from the post, a maneuver aimed at bypassing a challenge to his eligibility to fill the position.
item.dc:creator: Kamailoudini Tagba

media:content.media:description: Tidjane Thiam

item.title: Pakistan and India Shift to War of Words After Shooting Stops
item.description: Although the air strikes and artillery fire between India and Pakistan have mostly fallen silent, Pakistan Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif took aim at his counterpart over the border on Wednesday, accusing Narendra Modi of fanning instability and vowing a harsh response to future attacks.
item.dc:creator: Kamran Haider

media:content.media:description: Indian paramilitary soldiers stand guard along a busy road in Srinagar, on May 14.

item.title: Peru’s President Names Arana as Her New PM After Cabinet Crisis
item.description: Peruvian President Dina Boluarte promoted her justice minister to prime minister Wednesday after his predecessor resigned to avoid being ousted by congress.
item.dc:creator: Marcelo Rochabrun

media:content.media:description: President Dina Boluarte, left, with Eduardo Arana during a swearing in ceremony at the Government Palace in Lima, Peru, in this handout photo released by the Office of the Peruvian Presidency on May 14, 2025.

item.title: Newsom Blames ‘Trump Slump’ for California’s $12 Billion Deficit
item.description: California Governor Gavin Newsom unveiled a budget proposal that aims to close a $12 billion deficit, marking the third consecutive fiscal year in which state lawmakers need to plug significant shortfalls.
item.dc:creator: Maxwell Adler, Eliyahu Kamisher

media:content.media:description: The California State Capitol building in Sacramento, California, U.S., on Wednesday, July 7, 2021. California has reinstated a mask mandate for all lawmakers and employees at the state capitol regardless of vaccination status following an outbreak of nine Covid-19 cases there, reported the San Francisco Chronicle. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Brazil First Lady Complains to Xi About TikTok’s Effects on Kids
item.description: Brazil first lady Rosangela da Silva complained to China’s leader about potentially harmful effects of TikTok on women and children during an official dinner in Beijing, continuing a crusade against social media companies that has sparked controversy before.
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, Brazil’s president, right, and First Lady Rosangela da Silva

item.title: Bolivia President Arce Declines Candidacy, Calls for Left-Wing Unity
item.description: Bolivia’s President Luis Arce dropped his pursuit of reelection, calling for candidate Andronico Rodriguez to unite leftists ahead of the August vote and fend off a challenge from the right.
item.dc:creator: Sergio Mendoza

media:content.media:description: Luis Arce Photographer: Manuel Seoane/Bloomberg

item.title: IRS Can Only Give Tax Data to ICE in Deportation, Criminal Cases
item.description: The IRS can share taxpayer data with federal immigration officials only in cases involving immigrants with final deportation orders or ongoing criminal investigations, according to a newly unsealed agreement between the Treasury and Homeland Security departments.
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell, Jason Leopold

media:content.media:description: A US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents outside an apartment building during a multi-agency targeted enforcement operation in Chicago, Illinois, US, on Sunday, Jan. 26, 2025. President Donald Trump has pledged to carry out the largest deportation effort in US history, vowing to ultimately deport all of the foreigners living in the country without permission. Photographer: Christopher Dilts/Bloomberg

item.title: Newsom Wants to End Free Health Care for Undocumented Adults
item.description: California Governor Gavin Newsom is proposing to end free health care for most undocumented immigrants, walking back one of his signature policies as the state faces a drop in tax revenue.
item.dc:creator: Eliyahu Kamisher, Maxwell Adler

media:content.media:description: Gavin Newsom

item.title: China Pauses Rare Earths Exports Curbs Targeting US Entities
item.description: China on Wednesday suspended curbs on exports of rare earths and other goods and technologies for military use targeting 28 US entities as part of the trade detente struck between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Li Liu

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers at the Port of Los Angeles in Los Angeles.

item.title: Sanofi to Invest at Least $20 Billion in US Through 2030
item.description: Sanofi said it will invest at least $20 billion in the US through 2030, joining other pharmaceutical companies boosting their American operations as President Donald Trump threatens to impose tariffs and cut prices on drugs.
item.dc:creator: Eric Pfanner

media:content.media:description: A logo at the Sanofi SA campus in the Gentilly district of Paris, France, on Tuesday, April 25, 2023. Sanofi is due to report results on Thursday, with analysts focused on the performance of key drug Dupixent. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg
